message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms - painful menstruation, increased tampon usage, diffusely enlarged uterus - are indicative of adenomyosis, which is characterized by the invasion of endometrial glands into the myometrium. Option A is a sign of endometrial hyperplasia or cancer, which can cause abnormal uterine bleeding, while option B describes endometrial polyps. Option D refers to endometriosis, where endometrial tissue grows outside of the uterus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination suggest adenomyosis, which is the invasion of endometrial glands into the myometrium. Option A describes endometrial hyperplasia, option B describes endometrial polyps, and option D describes endometriosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest adenomyosis, which is the invasion of endometrial glands into the myometrium. Option A describes endometrial hyperplasia, which can lead to endometrial cancer. Option B describes endometrial polyps. Option D describes endometriosis, which is non-neoplastic endometrial tissue outside of the endometrial cavity. None of these options match the patient’s symptoms and physical examination findings as well as option C.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest adenomyosis, where endometrial glands invade into the myometrium. Option A describes endometrial hyperplasia, which may present with abnormal uterine bleeding. Option B describes endometrial polyps, which may cause abnormal bleeding or discharge. Option D describes endometriosis, but this usually presents with pelvic pain and/or infertility. None of these options explain the patient’s painful menstruation or diffusely enlarged, globular uterus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including painful menstruation and an enlarged uterus, suggest adenomyosis, which is characterized by the invasion of endometrial glands into the myometrium. The other options are related to endometrial cancer or polyps, which are less likely given the absence of abnormal uterine bleeding or discharge.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest endometriosis, and a diffusely enlarged, globular uterus indicates adenomyosis, which occurs when endometrial glands invade into the myometrium. Options A and B describe endometrial hyperplasia and endometrial polyps, respectively, which are not likely to cause a diffusely enlarged uterus. Option D describes endometriosis outside of the endometrial cavity, which can also cause pain but would not cause a diffusely enlarged uterus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of painful menstruation and increased tampon use, along with a mobile, diffusely enlarged, globular uterus, are suggestive of adenomyosis. Adenomyosis occurs when endometrial glands invade into the myometrium of the uterus, causing pain and heavy bleeding during menstruation. Option (A) describes endometrial hyperplasia, (B) describes endometrial polyps, and (D) describes endometriosis, none of which fit the patient’s presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has painful menstruation, increased tampon use and a diffusely enlarged globular uterus, which are concerning for adenomyosis. Adenomyosis is a condition where endometrial glands at the endometrium invade the myometrium. Option A describes endometrial hyperplasia, while option B describes endometrial polyps. Option D describes endometriosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including painful menstruation and the diffusely enlarged uterus, suggest adenomyosis. Adenomyosis is a condition in which endometrial glands invade the myometrium and can cause painful periods and a globular uterus. Option A describes endometrial hyperplasia, which can lead to cancer but does not cause a diffusely enlarged uterus. Option B describes endometrial polyps, which can cause abnormal bleeding but not a diffusely enlarged uterus. Option D describes endometriosis, which can also cause painful periods but typically presents with other symptoms and does not cause a diffusely enlarged uterus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest adenomyosis, which is characterized by the invasion of endometrial glands into the myometrium. Option A describes endometrial hyperplasia, option B describes endometrial polyps, and option D describes endometriosis.
